title: Excellent Take-out Japanese fusion lunch
text: We had a gift certificate which we used to enjoy an excellent take-out lunch: Iyasare kakiage tempura, suzuki yaki and sashimi mori. Portions were plentiful, enough for two lunches for the two of us. We would definitely order the same thing the next time. We know that if we had eaten the tempura, it would have been over-the-top excellent but by the time we got the dish home, it had lost some of the crispiness. The sashimi mori had a wonderful collection, but our most favorite plate was the grilled suzuki yaki (grilled sea bass). A wonderful treat in the time of Covid!!! Highly recommended. A big shout-out to Dan for helping us with our order.

title: The Bad and the Good
text: Overall we liked this place; however, there were a couple of incidents that were problematic. On our 2nd night, neither of our card keys wouldn't unlock the front door. It's a good thing we were returning to the condo before 11:00 pm when the front desk closes for the night. The cards had to be re-keyed. The second incident was on Day 3 . At check-in, we were told our condo would be cleaned on Day 3; however, no one showed up. A housekeeping attendant had come to deliver the extra blanket we requested and when we inquired about when our room would be cleaned, she had to check with the front office. Apparently the front desk forgot to notify housekeeping. We went out for an early dinner and when we got back, the trash was emptied, towels and amenities replaced. What we liked about the condo was the spaciousness, the kitchen set-up (coffee, dish detergent, sponge provided), and the washer/dryer. We were in Building 20 which is a long walk to the parking structure (and even longer walk to the front desk). We would recommend that housekeeping wash the kitchen floor which was dirty. At check-in, we were offered a discount card IF we attended a "session" which we knew to be a time-share presentation - we declined - and Holua was not pushy which we appreciated.
place: Holua Resort at The Mauna Loa Village

title: Decent combo pizza
text: We had a hankering for pizza and came upon this restaurant while shopping for groceries. We shared a 14" combination pizza with thin crust and a glass of merlot. Pizza was palatable. Total bill was $30.

title: We ate here for breakfast, lunch and dinner
text:
We ate here three times over a period of five days. Prices are a little high but food was delicious. The first time was for breakfast: one of us had the scumptious Ono Benedict and the other had the tasty homemade corned beef hash. Including two cups of coffee and tax, the bill was $40. We wished we could have returned for another breakfast because the menu was appealing.
The second time we came was for dinner. We shared a Caesar salad and red wine sangria. One of us ordered the Macadamian Mahi and the other the Hawaiian Ginger Ono. Both main dishes were satisfying. Bill totaled $89.
On our last full day in Kona, we lunch on Fish N Chips and the exceptional fish combo with battered fried mahi, calamari rings, and prawns. The tab was $39.

title: Decent Mexican food
text: We had driven to Waikoloa from Hilo in the morning and after having checked in, we were hungry, but we also wanted to explore the grounds. We ended up at the Boat Landing Cantina, an open air cafe by the Ocean Tower terminus of the tram. We shared Mahi tacos (2 on a plate for $22) and Taco Salad ($16) for lunch Food was decent and fresh, but perhaps on the pricey side.

title: Dined here twice
text: Both nights' dinners pleased us, but we were especially delighted by the first night's meal. We ordered the special fish dish with purple sweet potato, ginger monchong with sushi rice cake, tower of Maui onion rings, and a Moana Mule. Tab came to $144 including tax. The second night we shared a Caesar salad and the Seafood Tower for 2 (lobster, tiger prawns, Pacific oysters, and king crab leg). Bill including tax was $118. Be sure to make reservations with the concierge. The earliest seating we could get both nights was 6:30 pm. The first night we sat outside and got to experience a beautiful sunset. On the second night, the wind was so gusty that guests had to eat indoors.

title: Mid-afternoon snack
text: We enjoyed a mid-afternoon snack of delicious Mahi Tacos along with a mai tai. The food menu is simple with basic pub-type dishes. There are several large screen tvs offering sports channels. Good place to relax after a day in the sun.

title: Shout-out to Kelli, front desk reception
text:
We are multi-year Diamond HH members and having stayed at many of Hilton's hotels around the world, we expect a certain level of quality and service. We were on the Big Island at the start of the month, before the onset of Covid-19 in Hawaii. On this particular trip to the Big Island, we experienced the worst and best of the Hilton brand. Our stay in Hilo was disappointing and below Hilton standards. The night before we arrived at Waikoloa we tried to do a digital check-in but none of the offered rooms matched the Makai Ocean Front with lanai king bed room we had booked months ago. We called the Hilton Waikoloa and asked why we were offered a resort view (parking lot view) room instead of the ocean front room with lanai that we had reserved. The reservations desk clerk on the other end of the line advised us to talk to the manager upon our arrival at the Hilton Waikoloa. When we got to the registration desk, we were feeling rather tense and stressed and braced for another disappointment -- but Kelli calmly listened to our story, checked the registration, and gave us keys to Room 6304 which was a king bed room with ocean front view and lanai... exactly what we had reserved. It was Kelli, with her beautiful and warm smile, her serene and calming voice, her very helpful suggestions which enhanced our stay; and her genuine aloha spirit, that set the pace and tone for a most wonderful respite at Hilton's Waikola Village. Our biggest regret was that we had only booked a two-night stay; we wished we had added another night or two before moving on to Kailua-Kona. (We began in Hilo, stayed in Waikoloa, and then finished our trip in Kailua-Kona.)
Our room was equipped with iron and ironing board; robes; slippers; comp water bottles; spacious closet; full dresser; mini-fridge, Keurig coffee/tea maker, DVD player, and Kohala Spa coco-mango bath products.
We understand why guests don't want/need to leave the premises: the resort is self-contained. We loved the salt water lagoon which is ideal for snorkeling with plenty of large green turtles, tropical fish, and even a conger eel; access to the lagoon is via a sandy beach. Next to the lagoon is where guests can play, for a price, with dolphins. There are several pools and tennis court which we did not use. One can get lots of steps simply by walking and meandering throughout the resort. In the breezeways which connect all three towers are displays of museum-quality works of art, paintings, and objets d'art. There is a tram and boat which can transport guests from one tower to another but we chose to walk. As part of the resort fees, one can get ukulele, hula, and lei-making lessons; we opted to attend the ukulele lesson which was fun. The resort fees also include a complimentary photo. (Book 24 hrs in advance and allow about 30-45 minutes for the photo shoot.) If staying at the Makai Lagoon tower, the self-parking lot is close by; if staying at the Palace or Ocean Towers, then one might opt for valet parking. Breakfast is offered at the Big Island Breakfast hall. One can order a la carte or opt for either the continental or hot buffet. The continental breakfast ($28) is extensive and impressive with plenty of breads and pastries, exotic fruits, cereals, yogurts, parfaits, hot oatmeal, Chinese congee, and Japanese miso soup with all the fixings (e.g., tofu, daikon, pickles, kimchee, parsley, green onions). We did not opt for the "hot" buffet ($40) because there was way more than we could ever eat in one sitting: waffle station, omelet bar, pancakes, French toast, hot trays filled with meats, and other delights. We plan to return! Mahalo, Kelli, for your outstanding service and warm and hospitable welcome!

title: Smelly room; horrible breakfast; unhappy staff
text: We stayed at the Grand Naniloa and then at Hilton's Waikoloa. It was like night and day, worst to best. We hated our experience at the Grand Naniloa. At the Grand Naniloa, Ashlynn, the unfriendly and unhelpful desk clerk, did not acknowledge us as Diamond members, did not offer us water, did not give us our comp breakfast coupons. We ended up speaking to Sierra, another desk clerk, who graciously provided us with the comp water and breakfast coupons. Overall, it seemed the staff were not a friendly, happy group; dour seems an appropriate description; lacked the aloha spirit. We were assigned Room 328. The bathroom smelled like a combination of urine and mold. We used our carry-on Lysol spray in an attempt to mask the smell but were unsuccessful. We only travel with carry-on luggage (we never check luggage) so we were surprised by the severely limited storage space: no place to store luggage; a tiny closet (even small by European standards) and 2 small under-the-desk drawers; no dresser; no iron/ironing board. Breakfast at the hotel's Hula Hula restaurant was beyond dreadful and definitely not up to Hilton standards. The "cold" breakfast cost $16 for breads, cold cereals (no granola), yogurt, oranges, apples, a limit of 2 slices of papaya; a choice of passo-guava and orange juice; no apple or tomato juice; no peanut butter, no bananas . For $22, one can get the "hot" breakfast which is the never-changing oatmeal, scrambled eggs, bacon, Portuguese sausage slices, steamed rice, and breakfast potatoes. One can order off the menu instead of the buffet but we recommend leaving the hotel and finding a nearby breakfast restaurant. Parking is included in the $30 resort fee: one can choose between valet parking or self-parking in the lots across the street from the hotel. We've been Diamond members for years -- this is the most disappointing Hilton-chain hotel we've been to.
place: Grand Naniloa Hotel Hilo - a DoubleTree by Hilton

title: Counter-clockwise is easier on this 4-mile hike
text: Start early in the day, if only because parking is extremely limited at the Kilauea Iki Overlook. There are two ways to hike: clockwise, the more difficult direction which begins with an unpaved path, or counterclockwise, the easier direction which begins with going down steps. The descent to the crater floor is 400 feet... the ascent back to the parking area via the counterclockwise direction involves hiking switchbacks which is easier than climbing uneven, high, and steep steps if one has taken the clockwise direction. If in relatively decent shape, allow approximately 2 to 2.5 hours. Elevation/altitude is about 4,000 feet. The interpretative map/guide is available for $2 at the park headquarters and is worthwhile. Pack a hat/cap, sunglasses, plenty of water and insect repellent.

title: Local color - off the beaten path
text: Our Hawaiian friends took us here to experience some of the local color. It's a weekly (Wednesday nights) farmers market / arts and crafts fair/food court along with Hawaiian music and dance. It's off the beaten path and probably not high on the priority list of must-see/must-do for the average tourist.
place: Uncle Robert's Awa Bar and Farmers Market

title: Best place to buy Mauna Loa products
text: As others have pointed out, the farm/factory is not a "tour" although one can peer through the window to see the factory. This location is primarily a store/gift shop where you can get free tastings and the best prices on Mauna Loa products. We didn't believe the other reviewers about the prices being cheaper than Costco, WalMart, ABC and other stores, but it's true! We never knew there are 11 flavors of mac nuts; we have only seen a few of them heretofore: unsalted, lightly salted, Kona coffee, honey roasted, honey sriracha, mango chipotle, Maui onion and garlic, milk chocolate, milk chocolate coconut, milk chocolate toffee, and dark chocolate. The store offers other products as well including souvenirs, postcards, coffee, tea, jewelry, mugs, t-shirts, etc. Additionally, the store has a small cafe that serves reasonably priced food (e.g., hot dog) and ice cream. There were a lot of tour buses so it can get crowded. It's a fun place to go on a rainy day.
place: Mauna Loa Macadamia Nut Farm and Factory

title: Homecooking
text: Great restaurant. Generous portions. Have loved this restaurant ever since we first ate here over 30 years ago. As soon as our plane landed and we got our rental car, we headed to Teshima's for lunch. We had shrimp tempura as an appetizer and then ordered two pupu trays for lunch. Teshima's tempura is to die for... the batter is very light and crispy and not greasy. The pupu tray also came with bbq beef and sashimi. Yum! We like to eat here at least twice whenever we're in town.

title: Even Hilton's Hampton Inns serve a better breakfast
text: We're Diamond Hilton members so we were given vouchers for the continental breakfast with the option to pay $6 per person to "upgrade" to the Aloha buffet. We took the upgrade option the first day but decided it wasn't worth the price. We would advise guests to eschew the buffet and either order off the menu or go to a nearby restaurant. We could not believe how sparse and meager the breakfast offerings were. Even Hilton's budget chain, Hampton Inns, offers a free breakfast that's much better than the breakfast at this Hilo hotel. The "cold continental breakfast" included an assortment of breads (white and wheat bread, bagels, English muffins, croissants, orange and blueberry muffins, Danish; cottage cheese; fruits (limit of 2 thin slices of papaya slices, pineapple, thawed honeydew melon, apples, oranges); cereals (Frosted Flakes, Raisin Bran, Special K, Rice Krispies); juice (orange and passo-guava); and yogurt. Not to be seen anywhere in the buffet area were peanut butter, bananas, granola, waffle iron (staples offered at other Hilton chains); some other Double Tree hotels include cold cuts and cheese... but not the Hilo Double Tree. Oatmeal is considered part of the hot buffet! Cost for the cold buffet was $16 per person! For an additional $6, one can upgrade to the hot buffet which included oatmeal, scrambled eggs, Portuguese sausage and bacon, breakfast potatoes, steamed white rice, and French toast. Poor and unappetizing value.

title: Satisfying late afternoon meal
text:
We had spent the day hiking at Volcanoes National Park and returned to Hilo ravenous. We arrived for the HBC Afternoon Menu (in between lunch and dinner). We ordered a California Twist Sushi roll with tempura-style soft-shell crab as an appetizer, and two orders of fish and chips. The fish of the day was swordfish and surprisingly, the fish N chips were moist. Along with the Cock N Bull Ginger Beer, the tab came to $64.93 including tax for the two of us.
Good thing we arrived before the start of the dinner hour because there was already a line of people waiting to be seated for dinner. Highly recommended.

title: Very good food, but slow, inattentive service
text: We had lunch at the open-air Pineapples restaurant. We shared Fish and Chips and Seared Scallops, along with an Ola Cider glass (Dragonfruit and Lychee). The fish of the day was Mahi Mahi and we ordered the fish n chips furikoke style ($0.75 surcharge) and requested Sweet Potato Fries ($1 surcharge). The menu was enticing and the food was excellent and reasonably priced. Too bad service was slow and inattentive. The tab came to $ 37.96 including tax.

title: Good food; odd service
text: We were a party of 7 with reservations at noon. Five of us had arrived at 11:45 am and the hostess said she would seat us as soon as the remaining two arrived which they did about 5 minutes later.... to which the hostess said she wouldn't seat us until the stated reservation at noon -- in spite of the fact that it was a weekday, the restaurant was not at all crowded, and 6 other people had already been seated. We probably would have been seated earlier if we did not have reservations! We all thought this was odd. Food was decent enough - 4 out of 5 stars -- nothing really stellar. We ordered two crab dip appetizers; steak sandwich; 2 seafood louie salad; 2 mahi mahi stuffed with crab; 1 steelhead salmon; 1 cod and chips; iced tea; lemonade; Sprite; and 1 burnt cream. Total bill for the 7 of us was $282 including tax.

title: Excellent pizza; salad dressing too vinegary
text: We were two couples who lunched at the new location on 2nd and Mercedes, which is more spacious than the old location. One couple shared the Greek salad and Butcher Shop Pizza; and the other couple ordered the House salad and Favorite Pizza (sausage and crimini mushrooms). We loved our pizzas; however, we found the salad dressings way too acidic - wasn't sure if there was any olive oil. Also, on the House salad, the candied pecans were missing so we asked for some. There was a long line formed before the restaurant opened at 11 am on Sunday. By the time we finished lunch, there were still people waiting to get in. Highly recommended restaurant. Very reasonable prices - total tab was $70 including tax for the four of us.

title: Excellent pasta
text: We lunched at Belottis and shared a "small" antipasto which was more than ample for the three of us. We also shared three different pastas: Agnolotti di Lidia stuffed with beef, pork, sausage, spinach and escarole; Casoncelli pasta stuffed with beef, pork, prosciutto and sage; and Tagliatelle al cinghali (narrow pasta with wild boar). All the dishes were excellent and flavorful but the favorite was the Agnolotti di Lidia. One of us ordered a glass of Grecante Arnaldo Capral. Total tab including tax was $83.

title: Very good Mexican / seafood restaurant
text: We spent the late morning in Atwater to see the Castle Air Museum, then drove to nearby Merced to pick up maps at the California Welcome Center (which was closed on a non-holiday Monday!). Since there was no cafeteria at the Air Museum, we were hungry and noticed Lupians restaurant across the street from the Welcome Center. We entered the restaurant around 2:15 pm and ordered chicken enchiladas and chile verde. Both of us like spicy food so, while the plates were tasty, we requested fresh chopped jalapenos and hot sauce. The dishes were filling such that we didn't need/want dinner. Total bill including tax was $31. Service was excellent. Highly recommend.

title: Very good - request map before starting walk
text: From the road, the open-air museum does not look like much; however, once one enters the field, it's quite impressive. Be sure to get the map (it may cost $1) which allows you to identify each aircraft. We used our pedometer and the walk involved about 2,500-2,750 steps (about 1-1.5 mile looped path). Neither of us knows much about military aircraft nonetheless we found this attraction interesting. There is an indoor museum as well. We thought we would be able to see the museum in an hour, but we ended up spending two hours at the site. There is no cafeteria but vending machines are available.

title: Excellent Hampton Inn but not close to anything
text: No quibbles with this Hampton Inn other than it's not close to anything. Nearest shopping area with restaurants is 2 miles south. This hotel has the usual high standards one expects of Hampton Inns in terms of room, bed quality, appearance, cleanliness. Hampton Inns rotate breakfast offerings and on this visit we had scrambled eggs and bacon. Hotel was unusually crowded (sold out) due to the World Ag Expo.

title: Very good customized pizzas
text: We like this "new concept" pizza where you choose the crust, sauces, cheeses, and toppings. We've been here a few times now and we gravitate towards the thin crust with a combination of marinara and pesto sauces, double helping of spinach, mozzarella and gorgonzola cheeses, sausage and/or pepperoni, and depending on our mood, the addition of mushrooms, olives, artichokes and red onions. The restaurant offers "standard" pizzas such as cheese, margheritas, meat pizzas, but we much prefer to add more vegetables. Doesn't matter what toppings one wants, the price is the same. We experimented with toppings and decided that sometimes, less is better; too many ingredients obscure the flavors.

title: Pepitos Canyon Crest location
text: This was our first time at the Canyon Crest location. We met friends for dinner on Margarita Monday where the restaurant offers a 2-for-1 on margaritas. Food was very good and we were able to get separate checks. We ordered two margaritas (one regular blended and one mango blended), chili verde, and two chicken enchiladas. Bill was a reasonable $45 for two (including the discount on margaritas).

title: Boy Scout trail hike up to Observatory
text: We weren't sure how to get up to the Observatory since amber signs indicated that the parking lot was full. We did find a parking spot along Vista del Valle drive and it turns out we were right by the Boy Scout Trail head which leads up to the Observatory. The hike is a short, but somewhat steep 0.6 mile (we're senior citizens). There are views of the city and the Hollywood sign. The Observatory itself is educational... but it was crowded on the weekend. The cafe was horrible -- served ice-box cold hot dogs and the person behind the counter would neither heat the hot dog nor offered an exchange for a warm hot dog. Literally left a bad taste in our mouths.

title: Satisfying bun in a bowl
text: Saigon Dish offers satisfying dishes. One of us ordered #18 Yellow egg noodle soup with shrimp, pork and shrim wontons; and the other ordered #28 - Bun Tom Cha Gio Thit Nuong with grilled shrimp, grilled pork, and egg noodle salad. Prices are very reasonable and service is fast.

title: Smoking in hotel; crowded breakfast
text:
Really wanted to like this hotel but when we arrived, we could smell marijuana smoke emanating from a room by the 4th floor elevator. We're not anti-pot but when the hotel is supposed to be non-smoking, we don't expect the heavy smell of cigarette, cigar or pot smoke. We reported the smoke to the front desk -- they seemed aware of the issue. More smoke wafting out of the room on the 2nd day/night.
Breakfast was a zoo. The hotel does forewarn guests about busy times during breakfast service. Many trays and coffee pots needed replenishing. No English muffins - just plain white/wheat bread; bagels; and some pastries/muffins. First day had chicken fried steak with biscuits and gravy and reconstituted scrambled eggs. Second day offering was turkey and pork sausages, and scrambled eggs. Also available were make-your-own waffles, oatmeal, and cereals (fruit loops, honey nut cheerios, raisin bran).
There is a $15 per night parking fee. LAX is about 5 miles north.
place: Homewood Suites by Hilton Los Angeles Redondo Beach

title: Wonderful museum
text: We had seen the segment on CBS Sunday morning about the PostSecret exhibit and it did not disappoint. Reading people's secret letters was fascinating amd emgrossing. The museum had other worthwhile exhibits particularly the ones on cannibals, race, and beer!.

title: Short overnight stay, close to I-210 freeway
text: We arrived in the evening and left early in the morning before the breakfast service. Since we were unable to take advantage of the comp breakfast offered to Diamond members, we were given drink vouchers which was a nice touch. The hotel seemed a little dated, but we slept well (Room 1018) and access back to the freeway was easy. We would stay here again if we are in the area.
place: DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel Monrovia - Pasadena Area

title: Inexpensive Indian food
text: This is definitely a "quick vegetarian meal" cafe where food is served with paper plates, bowls, cups, and disposable forks/spoons. Don't expect anything fancy...but the food is tasty and plentiful. We had samosas, pakoras, dahl makhni, chana masala.

title: Decent when red meat craving hits
text: We generally don't eat red meat, but when the craving hits, Black Angus suffices. We remember the "bottomless salad" bowls days from decades ago when the chain restaurant first opened. The restaurant continues to give ice cold forks with the salad -- wish they would have forks at room temp; it's the plate that should be cold, not the forks. The prime rib and steaks are adequate; one shouldn't expect Ruth Chris / Morton's quality. We don't care for the underbaked cookie dessert. Take advantage of coupon specials. The Vallejo Black Angus is not open for lunch; dinner only.

title: Downhill from previous stay
text: We stayed at the Hilton Santa Clara back in 2017 and had a satisfactory experience so we expected the same level of service when we returned in 2019. We are Diamond members and used the digital check-in feature for Room 733 but when we arrived at the hotel, they said the room wasn't available and put us in Room 714. The room hadn't been well cleaned -- many live and dead gnats on the window sill and some stuck on the wall by the bed. From our previous stay, we knew the Exec Lounge would be not as good as other Exec lounges in terms of snack offerings, but we hadn't anticipated that the coffee machine would be out of service. We had the breakfast buffet in the restaurant but that was awful -- the bowl of cheese was rancid. The server didn't believe us until we told him to smell the bowl and sample the cheese. This hotel could stand some major improvements in housekeeping service and food quality.

title: Convenient location
text: As Diamond members, we got Room 1533 on the 15th floor facing the river. The room was comfortable enough. Shutters restaurant for breakfast felt claustrophobic. Fee for parking - best to book a room with parking included to get about a $5 per night discount. Hotel is located close to downtown region so restaurants are within walking distance. Wasn't the best, but certainly not the worst Doubletree we've stayed at.
place: DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel Spokane City Center

title: Odd layout; dark ambience; service lacking
text: We were en route to San Diego but wanted to visit a friend who lives in Santa Clarita; hence, one night at this Hilton Garden Inn. The layout is not typical Hilton Garden Inn; it's almost as though Hilton took over an old hotel and turned it into a Hilton Garden Inn. The location of our room (280) required walking down a long hall on ground level to take an elevator different from main elevator. When we got to our room, we wanted to put our food which required refrigeration in the mini-fridge; however, we couldn't because the fridge hadn't been cleaned out. We called housekeeping to remove the items. Not a good first impression. As Diamond members, our breakfast was comp but I think we have had better and more appealing breakfasts at other Hilton Hampton Inns and Garden Inns. The hotel felt old, tired, and worn. The dining area is dark with an old appearance. Breakfast staff seemed slow in helping guests. Place would benefit from lighting improvements. Can't say we would consider staying here again.
place: Hilton Garden Inn Valencia Six Flags

title: Suites on 5
text: As Diamond Hilton Honors members, our room was upgraded to one in the "Suites on 5" section of the hotel. The Suites, intended for extended residential stays, is in an annexed part of the hotel and requires card key access. The room (886) was equipped with a kitchenette in the living area and a separate bedroom. Very quiet and well-appointed furnishings. The housekeeping staff during our 4-night stay were superb. Our only complaint with the hotel was the breakfast dining area which we reported to management and for which we received a prompt response. Overall a very good hotel in a terrific location.
place: Doubletree by Hilton Philadelphia Center City

title: Allow 2-2.5 hours to view very fine art
text: There is a lot to see in this museum. It begins at the foot of the grand stairs leading up to the museum entrance where the Rocky statue is. Then get ready to climb the steep staircase. The first floor is currently closed for renovations and will re-open in 2020. We spent quite a bit of time in the European Art and Modern and Contemporary Art galleries. There's a wing for American Art, European Medieval to Early Renaissance art, and some Asian art.

title: Informative, interactive museum
text: We believe this museum is a very fine museum, better seen when one has more energy to appreciate all the details. This was our last stop of a very full day and we were low on energy, foot-weary, and hungry. That said, the exhibits were very well done and informative. The layout of the museum was well-curated and the lighting gave an intimate feel. Next time we visit this museum, we'll do it in the morning. We know we skipped reading a good amount of the historical material because we were tired. We plan to return here and give it its due time.

title: Reserve time entry tickets in advance
text: This is a must-see attraction which requires a timed entry ticket which should be reserved way in advance, especially during holidays, spring break, and summer. We went in October and could not get tickets for our first-choice date, so we re-juggled our planned itinerary around the date for which we could get tickets to Independence Hall. It seems to us the first place to visit in Philadelphia is Independence Hall for people interested in American history. (If you're an art aficionado, then the Barnes would be the first stop in Philly.) The park ranger provided an informative overview and history of Independence Hall, after which we were allowed to roam and explore the Independence Square buildings. To get or pick-up reserved tickets, go to the modern Independence Visitor Center which across the street from the entrance to Independence Hall.

title: Okay museum with room to grow
text: Some exhibits were very well done, especially the Feature Exhibition Gallery, Documents Gallery (American Treasures), and interactive Constitution exhibit while others seemed a bit hokey or wanting. The Signers' Hall has life-size bronze statues. The Road to Freedom theatrical performance was okay.

title: Fun snorkeling excursions
text: We booked with PWF a few years ago a snorkeling excursion to Lanai and enjoyed ourselves so much that we got a membership and booked two excursions this time: one to Lanai for the snorkeling, and the other to Honolua. Unfortunately, there were strong currents in Honolua thereby precluding the captain from anchoring there. Customers could ask for a refund or board the boat and let the captain take us to other sites. Glad we chose to board the boat. We snorkeled near Mala Wharf where we saw a white tip reef shark, turtles, tangs and parrotfish. Then we headed towards Olowalu Reef where we saw some spectacular marine life, including lots of turtles. Both excursions included lunch and beverages. Fabulous adventures.

title: The tour was worthwhile
text: I can't even remember how we found out about the Ocean Vodka distillery tours other than I had noted the tour in our planned itinerary before we left the mainland. We're sure glad we did the tour - it was $15 per person and included a 45-minute tour of the distillery and grounds, vodka/gin tastings, and a beautiful shot glass. The coconut rum was lovely, and the vodkas were nice, but the biggest and most pleasant surprise was the delightful refreshing ginger gin which turned out to be a disappointment because the gin is currently only sold at the distillery. :-( We were hoping it would be available at liquor stores on the mainland... hope Ocean manufactures the gin for commercial sale soon!
place: Ocean Vodka Organic Farm and Distillery

title: Upcountry cafe
text: Kula Bistro is a convenient place for breakfast when exploring Kula country. We remember this place when we were in Maui a few years ago and had a "short" stack (it really wasn't 'short!" -- it was huge!) before going to Haleakula for a hike. This year, we ate here before going to the Ocean Distillery and Ali'i Lavender Farm. We ordered crab cake benedict (which was okay -- too much breading), and mahi mahi benedict (excellent) along with coffee and cappuccino. Tab was $44.

title: Good breakfast options
text: From street level, walk down the stairs to the Down The Hatch restaurant. Place and pay for your order at the counter by the stairs and then look for a table. The restaurant offers vegetarian and non-vegetarian fare. Both of us ordered "bennies" - spinach-avocado benedict and seared ahi benedict with a side of bacon. Food was very good and tasty. Look for Maui coupon books (e.g., This Week Maui, Spotlight on Maui) for a coupon to Down the Hatch (Buy one, get second at 50%).

title: What a kick! Totally delightful adult shave ice!
text: We had lunch at Down the Hatch and on the receipt, it said we could get a 15% discount on a Breakwall Shave Ice. We delighted in the Pina Colada made with coconut ice cream, rum, pina colada flavoring and shaved coconut, and Mai Tai with mac nut ice cream, and light and dark rums. YUM!!! Recommend going during Happy Hour which begins at 2:00 pm for extra savings.

title: Decent Light lunch
text: Decent food for lunch. We shared an Upcountry Arugula Salad and 4-piece fish and chips plate. Because we arrived slightly after the restaurant opened for lunch, we were fortunate to be seated by the water's edge.

title: Food's great but service was inconsistent
text: We went to Three's Bar and Grill three times during our 10-day stay in Kihei: first time for Happy Hour dinner which was so delicious that we wanted to check out breakfast, and then the last time for dinner. We sampled the Brussel sprouts, Kahlua pig quesadilla, fish taco, flatbread salad, spicy tuna roll, nachos, kale salad, and for breakfast, the ahi benedict and breakfast sandwich. All the dishes were excellent except for the flatbread Mediterranean salad. For our second dinner, we opted for the kale salad. What prevents us from giving 5 stars is the inconsistent service which seemed to decline with each successive meal. On the third time, we waited nearly 25 minutes for the server to take our order. Our server spent quite a bit of time behind the bar talking to workers and serving drinks to bar customers.We timed her from when she said "I'll be with you in a moment" to when she returned to our table. Meanwhile, we witnessed customers who were seated after us being waited on by their servers. A shout-out to our first server, Max, who was fabulous -- especially since it was a busy Friday evening. The hostess/greeter was also excellent.

title: Under new management
text: We were in Maui in November and ate here on our first night. We learned the woman who ran the restaurant (since our last visit 3 years ago) had retired about a year or two ago. The menu appears to be the same. We shared the special Hawaiian Opakapaka steamed with broccoli, green onions, and ginger, and a large seafood pho soup. On a second visit, we had the clay pot rice and crispy chicken. Both meals were above average.

title: Went three times in 10 days
text: We enjoyed Nutcharee's so much that we went three times during our 10-day stay in Kihei. The first time we had papaya salad and cashew chicken, both of which were excellent, and a disappointing green curry fish. The green curry was much too thick for our taste. (In Thailand, green curry is more soup-like.) Nonetheless, we wanted to try other dishes. On our second visit, we ordered the "to-die-for" crispy fish, pad gra prao (seafood), and cashew chicken. We prefer not to visit a restaurant more than twice on any given trip; however, the second night's meal was so memorable and so tasty that on our last night on Maui, we went back a third time, this time ordering our favorite dishes: papaya salad, crispy fish, and cashew chicken. Really happy to have found this place!

title: Do the treasure hunt!
text: This was a whim-of-the-moment visit to the Ali'i Kula Lavender Farm. We're so glad we were in no hurry so we got to do the treasure hunt (a completed form with 12 different stamps) which yielded a delectable prize and to enjoy lavender tea, scones, and lilikoi jelly and syrup. The farm is very peaceful and fragrant. The farm sells lavender products including shea butter gardener's salve, hand creams, soaps, apparel, and the like. We bought several tins of the gardener's salve. Be forewarned that parking is on a rather steep hill. Recommend getting to farm in the morning as it closes at 3:45 pm. Before arriving at the farm, get a free copy of Upcountry Maui magazine and look for a $3 discount coupon which covers the entrance fee, not the guided tour portion. The treasure hunt gets you around the farm without the guided tour, although, the guide provides additional information. Surprisingly, we ended up spending 2 hours on the farm; we could have limited our time there to one hour if we didn't enjoy the scones and shop.

title: Taco Tuesday at Fred's!
text: We love eating at Fred's on Taco Tuesdays. Be sure to arrive early (no later than 5-5:30 pm) otherwise anticipate a long wait (up to an hour) for a table. Our favorite tacos are the Baja Fish, Mahi Mahi, and Ahi Tuna. Other taco fillings include carne asada, carnitas, chicken and shrimp. No napkins on Taco Tuesday, just a practical roll of paper towels.

title: Hearty breakfast
text: Moose McGillycuddy's is one of our go-to breakfast spots whenever we're in Kihei. Breakfasts are hearty with generous portions. We like the corned beef hash, huevos rancheros, the basic (eggs, potatoes, bacon/sausage, bread), and any one of the omelets (especially the spinach omelet). The short stack is huge! May order with mac nuts, banana, fruit. Check out "This Week" for coupons. Reasonably priced for Maui.

title: Great beach - life guard on duty
text: Whenever we're in Maui, we prefer to stay in Kihei at a hotel directly across from Kam Beach 1. Snorkeling is very good in the mornings when the water is calm. Unfortunately, this year in early November, there were tiger shark sightings which forced the closure of the beach for a couple of days -- apparently there were dead/dying fish from a damaged fishing net. When the beach finally opened, it had to be closed again, this time due to strong rip currents. Good thing there are lifeguards on the Kam 1-3 beaches.

title: Ideal hotel across the street from Kam1 beach
text: This is the third time we've stayed at Maui Coast Hotel. Hotel provides Gilchrist & Soames bath products; and the junior suite (625) is equipped with mini-fridge, microwave, coffee/tea maker, and bar sink along with tub/shower. The hotel does not have rooms which offer a full ocean view; the best one can get is a "partial" (obscured) view although the rooms have balconies. The daily resort fee includes free use of washer/dryer (detergent can be purchased), parking, newspaper, wi-fi. King bed was comfortable. The best aspects of the Maui Coast hotel is location: directly across the street from Kam I, around the corner from the best fish food truck, and within close proximity to many restaurants and shops. ABC is less than a block away. Pool is small and towels are provided.

title: Beginning to show its age; construction next door
text: The Hampton Inn-Missoula is one of our go-to hotels whenever we are in town because it has the advantage of being in close proximity to the freeway on-ramps and about 3 miles from the Missoula Airport. The staff are friendly and hospitable. This year, we were in Room 416 which overlooked current construction in the adjacent lot. This Hampton is beginning to show its age and could benefit from some improvements.

title: An architectural marvel with terrific views
text: Book online for free timed entry tickets two weeks in advance of planned arrival. There is a small elevator to accommodate those who are physically unable to climb steps. Great views of the Hudson River.

title: Make reservations for a delicious sushi feast
text: We were visiting a young friend who is studying in NY. When asked where he would like to have dinner, he suggested Sushi Yasaka. We had miso soup, sushi deluxe, sashimi deluxe, appetizer tempura, soft shell crab roll, hot sake, and red bean ice cream. Food was very fresh and delicious. Bill came to about $115 before tip. Worth every cent. Be sure to make reservations.

title: Our go-to place whenever we're in NYC
text: After a long cross-country flight, we like to have our first night's dinner in NYC at An'Nam where we'll order Pho to rehydrate and replenish our electrolytes. Our favorite dish on the menu is the steamed fish with vegetables prepared Chinese style with hot oil, soy sauce, and julienne ginger. For appetizers we typically order fried calamari and spider sushi roll. We consider this an Asian fusion restaurant with Vietnamese, Chinese, and Japanese offerings. We love this place (has nice ambience and full bar) and it's perfect for pre- and post-theater.

title: meh
text: We were hoping to find a good Mexican restaurant in Visalia. We didn't succeed with Alejandra's. We ordered crab enchiladas which we did not like along with a carnitas platter which was average.

title: Good meal, seems overpriced
text: We were in town for a family event and decided to have dinner at an old-time favorite restaurant. The two of us shared an ala carte salad, one of us had the salmon and the other had the halibut with one ginger beer. The tab was about $110 without tip. Tabs like this are common in the SF Bay Area, Los Angeles, NYC or any large metropolitan area, but it's still a shocker in small town Visalia. Food was decent, however.

title: Decent food and service
text: We were in town in late October for dinner. Shared the market salad and each of us had the grilled whole branzino. The meal was good, though a bit pricey for Visalia.

title: Tasty Ethiopian food
text: We were in San Jose for a conference and ate at Zeni's. We shared a vegetarian combo and a meat combo with a side salad and spiced Ethiopian tea. The platters were quite filling and delicious with ample injera to scoop up the dishes. Prices were quite reasonable - we spent just over $40 for the two of us.

title: Casual seafood restaurant
text: This is the kind of restaurant where you go up to the counter to order your meal. The fish is very fresh and expertly prepared. The aspect I don't like is having to find a table after putting in one's order. Sometimes one has to share a table so one should be prepared to forego privacy and converse with strangers.

title: Family reunion and long wait in spite of reservations
text: We were a party of 50 people in town for a family reunion. The reunion coordinator had reserved dinner at 6:30 pm but we weren't seated until 7:15 pm. We were all very hungry, especially the young kids, so lots of crying and crankiness. On the positive side, the restaurant allowed each family to get separate checks. Natalie was our server and she was fantastic in dealing with the huge clan. The chicken tostada and chili verde plate that we ordered was better than average. Normally would have given 4 stars but deducted a star for the extra-long wait to be seated in spite of having reservations.

title: Nice hotel with terrific front desk staff
text: We were in town for a family reunion. Although we were there at check-in, the room wasn't yet ready. The staff went out of their way to make us comfortable while we sat in the lobby. As Diamond members, we got comp water and snacks. The bedroom suite was equipped with a king bed and a separate living area with sofa bed. The bed was comfortable and it was nice to have a TV in the bedroom and living area since our nephew was with us. Given that this was a weekend and the hotel was at full capacity, the breakfast area was somewhat chaotic with not enough seating area. Overall, our stay was pleasant because of the staff.
place: Homewood Suites by Hilton San Diego Mission Valley / Zoo

title: Tomato Keftedes!
text: We had just finished a tour of Oia and before heading back to the cruise liner, we wanted to sample one of Santorini's most famous dishes, tomato keftedes made with tomatoes, feta cheese, and onions. We walked along Nomikou checking out restaurant menus and finally came upon Apsithia which offer the fried fritters made with Santorini tomatoes. Yum!!! The restaurant has a gorgeous view of the caldera. We were happy customers.

title: Good made-to-order pizza
text: My friend and I have been here twice and we were happy with our made-to-order pizzas. I ordered a pizza with thin crust, a combination of pesto and tomato sauces, double helpings of spinach, gorgonzola, mozzarella, sausage, mushrooms, and onions. My vegetarian friend loves the cauliflower crust with vegetables and cheese.

title: Ho-hum
text: Wanted to try a new restaurant that sells salad and ordered the Mediterranean salad with chicken. Nothing special - I didn't finish the salad because it was boring and tasteless.

title: Tourist restaurant
text: This restaurant was recommended by our tour guide. Since this was a tourist cafe, we knew not to have high expectations and thus, we were not disappointed with the fried calamari, saganaki (shrimp in tomato sauce) and Greek salad. The place was busy so service was on the slow side.

title: So glad we went to Delos
text: Back in 1971, Mykonos was already known as a party island. Forty-eight years later, it's still a party island, only more crowded and more expensive. We knew we would get off the cruise ship, disembark in Mykonos, and then immediately board another boat that would take us to nearby Delos for an archaeological tour. After we got back to Mykonos, we meandered the narrow alleys, had a late lunch, and took photos by the windmills.

title: One of Europe's oldest cities
text: Hubby and I are split about how to rank Knossos. He liked the Bronze-Age Minoan city while I wasn't as inspired given that we saw many other archaeological ruins on our 3-week Greek tour. The site is undergoing major restoration. The site lacks information plaques making it challenging to ascertain the structure one is viewing and its purpose. The most obvious structure, however, is the Palace with its vibrant frescoes. A guide, human or brochure, would be useful when visiting this site.

title: Oh yeah! Best way to escape the crowds!
text: I had been here 48 years ago, before there was electricity on the Greek islands, before the construction of the funicular, before the inundation of cruise ships and crowds. Was horrified to see that we had to wait over an hour to board the funicular to Fira and saddened by how overrun the island was of tourists. Fortunately, hubby and I wanted to hike the 8+-mile trail from Fira to Oia and avoid the crowds. Because we were on a cruise ship, we could not get an early start. Our tender did not get to the port until way after 9:30 am and by the time we reached the start of the trail in Fira, it was past 11:00 am -- already too late and too warm for optimal hiking conditions -- but we persevered because we knew it was either now or never. It took us about 4 hours of hiking (we're senior citizens) before we found the bus stop in Oia. This was one of our top three highlights of our Greek adventure. The trail was not crowded once we got past Imerovigli. Wear sturdy walking shoes (paved, unpaved, rocky, cobblestoned paths), pack plenty of water, wear sunscreen and hat with wide rims.

title: Interesting museum if you have the time
text: We were on an organized tour of the island which included a visit to this museum. It is a nicely curated and informative museum, especially given its compact size. One gets a glimpse of the geologic origins of Milos; the sociological, economic, and technological aspects of mining; and the various minerals which can be found on Milos.

title: Spectacularly gorgeous
text: On our tour of Milos, we stopped at Sarakiniko Beach. The area is spectacularly scenic with the stark, white stone contrasted against a deep blue sea and sun-lit blue sky. Swimmers and sunbathers abound, as well as hikers.

title: Worth the time and effort
text: We were on a cruise ship and opted to go on the Delos tour rather than hang out in Mykonos (been there, done that decades ago). Good choice. The island is now uninhabited and requires taking a ferry from Mykonos to Delos. Once we disembarked, we met up with a tour guide who was quite informative. One got a sense of how bustling a place Delos was. Time permitting, it's worth a quick trip to the museum before boarding the boat back to Mykonos. Time on Delos was time well-spent.

title: Interesting Meteora monastery
text: Varlaam is the second largest of the 6 surviving monasteries. This monastery shows how the monks were able to ascend and descend using nets and ropes. There is a 16th century oak barrel which stored water as well as a small museum housing painted icons. Seven monks still live in the monastery. No photos allowed and one must wear modest clothes - no shorts, no sleeveless shirts.

title: Nunnery
text: Roussanou is one of 6 surviving monasteries out of the original 24. Today the venue is a nunnery. No photos are allowed but we were able to see the chapel and the gardens. There is a small shop selling Catholic items.

title: Tour group hotel
text: This hotel was the least favorite of our tour group hotels... but thankfully, we didn't spend much time in our room since our group arrived before dinner and we checked out early morning after breakfast. It's an average hotel with nothing special to distinguish itself. Dinner and breakfast were adequate.

title: Decent hotel for tour group
text: We were part of a tour group that stayed in this hotel. The hotel was modern and the hallways stark. Decent room. The breakfast and dinner buffets were adequate and filling. Service by front desk staff was very good and responsive.

title: Good compact museum
text: Highlights of this museum include bronze works, the Sphinx of Naxos, kouros statues, pediments and friezes from the Temple of Apollo, and the bronze Charioteer of Delphi.

title: Spiritual
text: We weren't prepared for the spirituality and energy we derived from visiting legendary Delphi. It is an amazing and fascinating archeological site. As you make your way up the Sacred Way, you'll walk past the Roman Forum. It's easy to miss the small cone-shaped Omphalos, between the Treasuries and the Treasury of the Athenians, which marks the center of the world. Continue walking and you'll reach the imposing Temple of Apollo. Look upwards towards the hills and you'll see people climbing towards the theater. If you are able-bodied, it's worth climbing to the theater; and, if you are fortunate, you'll get an inexplicable surge of energy which will take you beyond the theater to the Stadium. All the hiking from the entrance to the top where the stadium is and back down can be done within 2 hours. Wear sturdy walking shoes and bring water -- very little shade until you reach the stadium.
